text:
Hey B2B pals :wave:

Here's another thing I'd like your take on→ t*he B2B world doesn’t need more content. It needs more strategic editors*.

In my experience, a lot of B2B companies push out content that:
• Doesn’t rank, because it’s not been optimised Doesn’t help, because it’s not addressing real customer needs
• Doesn’t help, because it’s not addressing real customer needs
• Doesn’t educate, because it’s written from the PoV of a product person, not an end user
• Doesn’t convert, because it’s not spelling out tangible value
• Doesn’t stand out, because it’s just the same ol’ stuff everybody else is doing
The industry doesn't need more of the above—but it can do with training strategic editors whose main job is not to fix typos but to ask "who is this for and why should they care?" about every. single. piece. you. ship.

Having someone in that role, for us at Hotjar, was the difference between a bunch of well-intentioned but disconnected and underperforming content AND a strong content machine that created awareness, built brand, and drove growth.

What's your take? Do you have strategic editors on staff—and if not: who is your go-to on the team for that kind of work?

text: My whole take is, “YES!” Volume without close, constantly assessed strategic alignment and optimization is a wasted effort. There is so much worthless content out there and as content increasingly becomes a revenue driver and sometimes a product in its own right, the approach you describe is what will actually differentiate your brand.

elements.text: My whole take is, “YES!” Volume without close, constantly assessed strategic alignment and optimization is a wasted effort. There is so much worthless content out there and as content increasingly becomes a revenue driver and sometimes a product in its own right, the approach you describe is what will actually differentiate your brand.

text: This gives me hope ^ — I spent a couple of hours today researching a bunch of B2B things and I wanted to cry :joy:

elements.text: This gives me hope ^ — I spent a couple of hours today researching a bunch of B2B things and I wanted to cry

text: Yes, I think a lot of companies hire content producers while overlooking the importance of content strategists. So many executives think they can play the role of content strategist by just assigning every idea that pops into their brain and then they wonder why it doesn’t work.

elements.text: Yes, I think a lot of companies hire content producers while overlooking the importance of content strategists. So many executives think they can play the role of content strategist by just assigning every idea that pops into their brain and then they wonder why it doesn’t work.

text: This is exactly how we’ve been approaching briefing and strategy! Unfortunately because our core team is small I’ve been the one asking those questions, but i agree that they’re absolutely necessary for a content driven company

text: I think the standing out part is probably the most time consuming step—requires the most care and thought (compared to say.. optimizing for SEO)

text:
:wave:  Following up question to an awesome question <@U017WRJTKF1>!

My team is organized in such a way where content ownership is scattered across the map - blog, social, webinars, podcast, video, newsletter are all owned by different people. Our CMO is driving the strategy, but their attention is not 100% focused on content (rightly so).

My colleague that owns the blog is driven by shipping content (volume = traffic) but some of the content that goes out is barely edited and some downright bad. I ducked into our blog metrics and yes, traffic is there but bounce rate is unacceptably high.

My Q: *On a lean team where ownership is horizontal across roles, how do you position yourself / advocate to _become_ the strategic editor?* How do you offer critique to help align on quality without coming off as judgemental or overstepping into someone else’s domain? Anyone who has done this on your team?

I’m coming from a place where I _really_ care about our brand messaging but want to offer criticism that will incite change and improvement. I don’t like complaining without solutions. Thanks for any advice!

text: Wow, all different owners?! That’s wild and definitely sounds like you’re overdue for some consolidated strategy.

elements.text: Wow, all different owners?! That’s wild and definitely sounds like you’re overdue for some consolidated strategy.

text: Do you report to the CMO?

elements.text: Do you report to the CMO?

text: If so, it might be a good idea to bring a rough outline for an overarching strategy, and then get their permission to move ahead with building out a more robust plan.

text: I would think bigger than, “Let me edit the blog posts for brand voice before they’re published.”

elements.text: I would think bigger than, “Let me edit the blog posts for brand voice before they’re published.”

text: Part of the strategy might be analyzing all the different messages being put out by these various channels (do they align with the company’s priorities? are they consistent with those goals? are your buyers getting mixed messages if they interact with you on those different channels?) and then ensuring they’re aligned with the key pillars.

elements.text: Part of the strategy might be analyzing all the different messages being put out by these various channels (do they align with the company’s priorities? are they consistent with those goals? are your buyers getting mixed messages if they interact with you on those different channels?) and then ensuring they’re aligned with the key pillars.

text: yes, +1. I would make an argument about the importance of a consistent tone of voice + strategic consolidation across multiple formats, so that your audiences know it's you regardless of what they're reading/consuming from the brand _and_ so that you're all jointly driving in the same direction and maximising your chances of success instead of owning smaller pieces of the large puzzle that might conflict with one another

<@URAV154AV> <@U017WRJTKF1> Thanks for validating that I’m not crazy :joy:

Ya I report to the CMO and I’ve brought these issues / my frustrations up and expressed that I want to be more involved on the overarching strategy piece. I think an audit of all the content channels and goals might be a good place to start. Also bringing more visibility into the quality of what we’re shipping.

text:
<@UMX8MPHA6> I enjoyed reading down the thread wondering if there would be an opportunity to chime in. You gave yourself the suggestion that I had - way easier said than done, but can you audit the channels around
1. audience for each channel, 
2. content pillars/messages emphasized in each channel
3. Within a channel, relative volume of content supporting a core pillar vs. widely dispersed topics
4. Relative performance of channels vs. benchmarks for the channel
?

text:
Thanks for chiming in <@U018T15N7GW>!

#1 really resonates - I think going back to basics and consolidating our content across channels and asking “who does this serve?” and “how does building this relationship support the business?”

Then using this to better articulate #2 with the outcome of defining what our pillars are and using that as a foundation to consolidate.
